hedline.hl1: Heat Loses Grip on the Fans

abstract.p: Miami Heat management, apparently weary of having its home-court advantage diluted by supporters of other teams, offered free Heat clothing in exchange for any opponent's merchandise (S)

block.p: Before the Miami Heat began its series with the Knicks, Heat management, apparently weary of having its home-court advantage diluted by supporters of other teams, offered free Heat clothing in exchange for any opponent's merchandise.

The offer drew a response from hundreds of fans. About 1,500 pieces of clothing were traded in, at least a third of it from Knicks fans. Yet that may have been the proverbial drop in the bucket. When the Knicks play the Heat Wednesday night in Game 5 of their four-of-seven-game playoff series, about half of those filling American Airlines Arena will have allegiance to the Knicks. The Heat's owner, Micky Arison, is a former resident of Queens who rooted strongly for New York-area teams until he moved to Miami with his family almost 35 years ago.

Before the Miami Heat began its series with the Knicks, Heat management, apparently weary of having its home-court advantage diluted by supporters of other teams, offered free Heat clothing in exchange for any opponent's merchandise.

The offer drew a response from hundreds of fans. About 1,500 pieces of clothing were traded in, at least a third of it from Knicks fans. Yet that may have been the proverbial drop in the bucket. When the Knicks play the Heat Wednesday night in Game 5 of their four-of-seven-game playoff series, about half of those filling American Airlines Arena will have allegiance to the Knicks. The Heat's owner, Micky Arison, is a former resident of Queens who rooted strongly for New York-area teams until he moved to Miami with his family almost 35 years ago.

''If I had to pick one thing that I can't understand as a fan it's the issue of Knicks fans that are not from New York, do not presently live in New York,'' Arison said. ''I don't mind if a fan comes here and has a John Starks uniform and all that. If he lives in New York, that's fine.''

Arison takes exception, though, when someone who has lived in South Florida for at least a decade still roots openly for the Knicks against the hometown team. ''I find that very unfortunate, very frustrating.''
